comments.commentBody: Donald Trump once told me that the only man he really feared in this world was this man, Murdoch.  'Why,' I asked.  'Because he will say anything, do anything, but he will get you in the end, he will get you better than the mob ever would.'

I have a perspective different from that of the writer and many of the commenters here.  I grew up in a major city in the U.S., and by the age of 8 or so was allowed to travel with my friends by bike to the school playground and elsewhere in our larger neighborhood unsupervised by adults.  The playground kept our interest only for a short while, on occasion, then we were off to play chase, kickball, or whatever.  I don't understand the concern being expressed that playgrounds are boring for older kids -- my experience is that that was always the case.  And as a younger child I would have been thrilled to have the type of playground equipment that is common now -- it lends itself to great games of tag and imaginary play, as demonstrated by my 5-year-old.

The answers provided by the Murdochs, especially the highly operatic interruption by Rupert to say how sorry he is, represents a heavily rehearsed tear jerking performance deserving an Oscar. The crocodile has shed its tear. I am afraid they will get away with murder.

Seems to me that if a company is so big you don't know what's going on, you need to make it smaller - or government regulators need to insist that it be smaller.

How is it acceptable to say - well, I didn't know about that, so how can I be responsible for it?

You're the boss, mate. You built it, you made it, you own it. It happened because you made it happen, you let it happen, and then you failed to stop it happening.

So if you fail to conduct yourself as a human being, and instead choose to view your performance solely through the prism of profit generation, then you're no leader. Not in the true sense. Leadership is all about responsibility - and you've failed the first test.

This era of business leaders who refuse to accept responsibility for the things that are done in their name has got to stop.

If you wondered what the difference is between an inefficient governmental bureaucracy and a cutting-edge private business, it’s the sense of responsibility. As you know, two highest ranking police commissioners in Britain resigned over the phone hacking while Mr. Murdoch, the owner of the tabloid that bribed the police officers and hacked the phones of innocent victims, stubbornly maintained he had no idea what was going on in the flagship of his media empire and the most selling newspaper printed in the English language in the world.

Isn’t it even stranger that the FOX News Network persistently claimed that the Pakistani government must have known who was hiding in a house in a country with almost 200 million people while it was normal for them that the owner of a British tabloid had no idea what his editors in chief were doing.
The journalism prone to the intentional misleading of public, full of double standards and hypocrisy cannot serve as a watchdog.
